Review title: A twisty-turny masterpiece
Review_body: A great eighties thriller that actually delivers on what it promises. Hackman, Costner, and Patton give great performances, with only Young lagging slightly -- the viewer is never entirely sure what attracted Brice to Susan in the first place. Perhaps the scene in the limo is an example of her four-sheets-to-the-wind personality. It certainly ensnared Costner.Much has been said about the last five minutes of the film. It's a great use of the "Yuri" red herring that runs throughout the film, though it doesn't necessarily add anything to the story, other than to reinforce the paranoia that no one really is who they seem, and no one can be trusted. An ideal twist is one that isn't needed to enjoy the film -- here, it's not needed but only muddies the water in terms of where sympathies lie.The one aspect of this film that truly doesn't stand up is the score. A horrible late-eighties synth soundtrack fills in where a Bernard Herrmann-esquire orchestra would have done nicely and reinforced the Hitchcockian nature of the story. Still, however, a well-done film.

Review title: Do NOT recommend
Review_body: My husband and I both agree that this movie sucked. The acting was terrible. The plot we've seen in 3 different movies. The only reason we watched the whole thing is because we were bored and it's such a pain in the butt to find something else. Don't waste your time.

Review title: Childish, amateurish pseudo-thriller...and the VERY type of movie that the Red Scare was warning about
Review_body: The local NY tri-state area PBS station has movie nights every Saturday and for the longest time, it aired classics. Now it plays warmed over junk. I had never see No Way Out when it was first released, but as soon as I saw the opening credit, I knew this was trash.Let me get to what's wrong with this movie from a strictly storytelling standpoints. It's a pseudo-thriller, in the vein of Marathon Man and Black Sunday. An actual thriller is supposed to be taut, suspenseful and plausible, and the twists and turns both sophisticated and clever. Pseudo-thrillers fake sophistication by making the story either convoluted or bogging the story down in what are known as "red herrings." There will be tons of chase scenes and dialogue with characters that really, when you get down to it, are there to throw you off track.This movie has stuff like this in spades. The story is so unsophisticated, so crude, that you could sum it up in one paragraph: a high ranking US official accidentally kills his mistress. Fixers cover up the mess by trying to frame a known Russian spy. The "hero" of the movie realizes what's happening and keeps running from the bad guys--a lot. There's no real investigation to be had here because...DING DING DING...turns out HE is the Russian spy that the fixers are trying to pin the murder on!All of this is played out in such a clunky, amateurish fashion that it's cringe-inducing from beginning to end. The editing is so terrible that I couldn't even follow what was going on more than half the time. The prelude to the murder is so obvious I practically started laughing. (Oh, there is a staircase. Oh, look, they're fighting near the staircase. Oh, gosh, wonder what's gonna happen? WHOOPS! Didn't see that coming!) Everything else that happens is bad, cheesy, obvious.The only remotely decent and legitimately inspiring moment in this movie is when Gene Hackman's character turns on the one person who's so loyal to him that he was willing to kill and risk his reputation to protect him. But that's about it.Now, let me get to this twist that everyone is raving about it. People praising it don't understand why it's there. This is not a twist meant to be clever. It's meant to be subversive. By that I mean, the movie sets you up to think that Kevin Costner is the All American Hero who has such a duty to his country that he will even undermine his "superiors." But the twist is that he wasn't one at all. He was a Russian spy.The fact that he was the Russian spy puts the entire movie in a new light. It's not about American patriotism. It's about the morally upstanding and so much smarter Russians exposing how thoroughly bankrupt the American political system is and Americans are. Americans are so corrupt that they will even sell out their own mothers, their best friends.This is literally the type of subversive stuff that had an alcoholic Senator McCarthy raving about in the 1950s. He may have been a fall down drunk and megalomaniac, but he is 100% right on the money about how there were elements in Hollywood that were trying to use movies to undermine American values. Incidentally, the fresh-faced, All American Boy Next Door Kevin Costner would be used for the exact same purpose in another subversive movie, JFK. I mention his look because subversive filmmakers like Stone and this particular one for No Way Out were smart enough to realize that Americans would be more willing to accept their subversive movies if they cast an actor with the perfect "All American, apple pie. Wholesome" look to him that would cause Americans to trust the film implicitly.

Review title: Good political thriller
Review_body: Saw No Way Out the other night for the first time in over 20 years. It happened to be on TV and my wife, who has never seen it, and I decided to sit down and watch it after I told how good it was.For the first 15/20 minutes I wondered if I had been remembering the same film. Those first 15 minutes or so make you think that you are watching some straight to video 1980's cheap thriller. But once you get past that first wee while, it kicks in and you get swept along with it.There is the twist, and as others have suggested, it does seem a bit rushed. It's as if they didn't quite know how to end the film or ran out of time and/or money.Costner, Hackman and Young give good performances. The likes of George Dzundza and Fred Dalton Thompson give their usual solid support. Will Patton does tend to over do it slightly.Never the less, if you haven't seen it, and want a decent thriller to pass a couple of hours, you could do a lot worse than catch No Way Out.

Review title: One of my favorites!
Review_body: 15 years later, this one is still an awesome movie.  First half of the movie develops at its own pace (Some call it slow), but shows the depth of passion growing between Costner and Young.(Spoiler Ahead)Once the murder happens, the movie kicks into high gear - a real gripping thriller that keeps you on the edge of your seat.  The time pressure adds an outstanding level of tension you can cut with a knife - or a straight razor!The scene where Yuri is 'revealed' shows just how crazy people in power can become, and the surprise twist at the end had me wanting to hit the rewind button in the theater if one existed.This one is a must see!

Review title: It's philosophy, not Action or politics!
Review_body: I think y'all are missing the point of this movie - especially those of you who think the ending should be dropped.In the end, the questions we are left with are those of ethics and morality: if I use false or fabricated information to arrive at a true answer, am I wrong? Should I be punished? Should I not pursue the conclusion? If I fight against a cover- up, but all of my other representations are false, should I be trusted or believed in my one instance of honesty? Should I be allowed to get away with my trespasses?This movie challenges the viewer to reflect on these issues, which would not exist without the current ending.Finally, this is Kevin Costner at perhaps his most perfect, luscious moment. Worth seeing once!

Review title: Find a way
Review_body: Another potentially intriguing movie ruined by ridiculous car chases, unbelievable coincidences, and an insipid ending which gives the viewer a cheap thrill, but once examined makes no sense whatsoever when one recalls how the characters behaved throughout the film and the motivations for their actions.Don't buy it, don't rent it, and don't waste time watching it.

Review title: Amazing performances, writing and directing
Review_body: The first great movie I watched. Gene Hackman is a great actor, but for this viewer, in this movie he is the fourth most impressive cast member. Amazing performance by Will Patton as the utterly loyal aide, Costner is nothing short of mesmerising, and Sean Young is excellent. Amazed that Costner and Patton, and the writers and director not considered for Oscars for this movie, but what do I know.

Review title: Political Thriller
Review_body: I remember seeing this when I was twelve and home one day and thought it was brilliant. Gene Hackman can pull off any role and his portrayal as Defense Secretary David Brice really won me over! Kevin Costner was absolutely gorgeous when he was younger and isn't bad now. Sean Young looks crap these days but was really beautiful back when she was twenty-eight. Tom Farrell is a navy officer who gets posted at the pentagon and is to report to the secretary of defense David Brice. At a party one night he see's a very beautiful woman across the room. Her name is Susan Atwell and she is having an affair with the secretary. They go to her best friend's place Nina Beka, played by a thirty-two year old Iman. The scene in which they're in the limo together and are already getting their clothes off is actually quite raunchy. And Sean Young had a great body back then so she pulls it off well. During their affair he asks her numerous of times to leave the secretary but she wont. During fun and games she takes a Polaroid of him which he scrunches up and chucks under her bed. During a fight between the secretary and herself Susan is killed. The secretary devices a ploy to frame someone. The Polaroid image is found but seems to be ruined. The team in the Pentagon try to regenerate the photo. They can make out a man and they decide that he who is in the Polaroid is the killer. SO Tom has only a few hours to do something about it. Will he be framed for the murder of the woman he loves or will he escape and prove the secretary the KGB mole? Watch it and find out it's a great film! If you like Sean Young I recommend her in 1991's "A Kiss Before Dying" which I only saw only on television days after I saw "No Way Out" on television.

Review title: A good movie ruined by absurd background research.
Review_body:
A low-grade spoiler is that the foreign spy was known to be inside the Pentagon. All the doors were locked and the heros conducted a room-by-room search...of the Pentagon, which happens to be the largest office building on Earth.
If this were a cop movie, Starsky and Hutch would pile into their red-and-white Ford Gran Torino and speed about L.A., chasing a tip that the Soviet spy was wearing a green knit cap. Surely we can find the Commie snitch! Obviously, nobody who pre-productioned the movie had ever been in the Pentagon.
In another howler of a gaffe, the grateful Soviet spy agency offered a spy a special reward - the opportunity to return to (his/her) beloved Russia. In the real world USSR of the time, any spy would have chosen employment as a prison janitor in Needles, California, over returning to the paranoid and dull world of the USSR. Look it up. Again, bad pre-pro work turns a decent movie into a giggle-fest.

Review title: Definitely underrated first-class thriller
Review_body: There are only a fistful movies I gave 9 points. This is one them. After watching it I immediately had an itch to watch a sequel (regrettably impossible due to the story line). Didn't actually want it to stop and was sad that it ended. (True for just a few other movies, like for example Dr. Zhivago or 12 Monkeys) When I checked the IMDb - rating composition to find out why this movie is so grotesquely underrated, I asserted that the IMDb Staff gave 8 points, anyway. (Phew!) One of the very few US-thrillers, the end of which I wasn't able to predict. Gene Hackman and Kevin Costner are habitually brilliant, Will Patton deserves an Oscar as the best supporting actor in my book.

Review title: Skip the last five minutes
Review_body: This movie is great, but why did they ever add the last five minutes. I was OK with the story of Farrell being used by men at the top. I didn't need any surprising switch, especially one that is not necessary to explain the story so far.The revelation at the end of for example "The Sixth Sense" is good. There you see something happening that helps you understand the movie you have just seen. It leaves you puzzled for a while, replaying the entire movie again in your head. Nothing like that happened at the end of "No way out".But then again, the movie's great.

Review title: As suspenseful as 'Mystic Pizza!'
Review_body: "You have no idea what men of power can do!"A truly awful movie. Every twist and turn telegraphed: from the 'accidental push over the balcony railing' to the 'placing of the gun just within reach of the bad guy.' As an added extra bonus, the groan-inducing, stomach punch of the last scene, sinks this movie to transcendental awfulness.IT IS ALL HERE FOR YOU: Costner cardboard acting: CHECK Sean Young looniness: CHECK Handicapped genius killed in cold blood: CHECK Bad Guy who is latently in the closet going homicidal: CHECK Gene Hackman not-so-good-guy-turns-sympathetic-at-end: CHECKSee it at least once because everyone's movie-viewing system needs a good flushing once in awhile!

Review title: From the depth of fourth time around
Review_body: I've just hauled this off the shelf and watched it for the umpteenth time. Flawed though it is, I love it. The controversy amid reviewers is surprising to me; but perhaps I don't watch sufficient "thrillers" to have a list of expectations--which several folks seem to have found unfulfilled. Spoilers: "No Way Out" is composed of one surprise after another...a series of surprises, if you will. From learning that Tom and Susan's original meeting was contrived by others to the shock of her murder, to the reappearance of the forgotten Polaroid negative, to the murder of the IT man and the final scene, with its suspense-filled last scene, I--as a repeat viewer--was constantly aware of Tom's reaction to every incident in the light of what the ending revealed to us....as well as what it did not. The last line, "let him go. He'll be back. He has nowhere else to go" is so poignant.This is very early Costner. The work of a business administration major who suddenly decided he wanted to act. The subtleties in what I understand was only his second performance are astonishing. If you didn't like it, forget it. but if you did, I strongly recommend watching it at least three times.

Review title: Enjoyable romp- just one thing though...
Review_body: The music was truly awful- typical 80s electronic trash, which immediately dates the film. I love movie music but this surely could have been done so much better. Shame, really, because it wasn't too bad a movie!

Review title: Great movie!
Review_body: Excellent, thought-provoking, intricately crafted thriller, with plenty of plot twists and turns.  This is one of the most under-rated movies of the last twenty years. One of the first movies to show how things in Washington may actually work...

Review title: Good
Review_body: It takes quite a while to get going and the film is firmly rooted in the 80s, not just from a storyline perspective, but also in terms of its production. The only meaningful female role is poorly developed, although Young does her best with what she has and the relationship between her and Costner feels forced. The score is also dreadful. But once the main plot kicks in, this becomes an intriguing conspiracy thriller as Costner attempts to stay one step ahead of the investigation he is heading. Hackman is surprisingly low-key here, but Will Patton as his right-hand man and Costner's main antagonist is good value. It is also a film that is defined by its great ending, a scene that is surprisingly low-key in its delivery, but works extremely well in the context of the overall film. It's a shame that repeat viewings don't really offer much to reevaluate characters and plot points as a result but it still makes for a clever resolution.

Review title: Dissapounting finale
Review_body: Great acting throughout... Loved the storyline but was disappointed at the ending.
